author: Remik1188

description.text:
Some kind of door for in spaceships or something. Rotate the rings to open/close.  
Edit: I uploaded some new files that should make it easier to open/close it.  
Edit2: There's a new Door_part that should prevent the ringthing from snapping when it's all the way open, (in theory. I haven't tested it (yet)). I let the old one online for people who like it ;)
Print 6 parts and remove supports at the rotating point. Print an outer and inner ring. Assemble. Have fun.

For my 3D printer I wanted to have a possibility
to load different tools onto my X Carriage without much effort
e.g. Hotend, Drill, Dial Gauge ....
As I did not find something matching, I decided to create something
by myself.
Eventhough the result looks quite nuclear, its not radioactive at all
and even easy
put the two Halves together, rotate by 45 degrees and lock it with
a simple stick(e.g. nail) . This results in a firm connection. I have attached the source STL file so the quick mount can be parameterized, and of course assembled to your design. Just make sure during design already that ,the hole of the first half points up and the hole of the second half points down I am sure, it can also be used in other areas but 3d Printers ...

Integrate the SCAD File into your design and print it. The Handles are there to be able to operate the quickmount in the
absence of something useful. its difficult to rotate a circle ;) its advicable to use a layer thickness of < 0.3mm so the teeth
become smooth.

description.text: This is a combination remix of the dwarf and thief flat minis.

Tower 1 displays the 168 primes less than 1000 on a stack of 16 prisms  They fit neatly as the sum of the numbers from 3 through 18 is also 168.  Tower 2 can display any 130 consective primes from the set of primes less than 10000.  As given here it shows the 130 primes following those on the first tower.  The third tower is a small ornament made by cutting tower 1 off after 6 layers.  It displays the first 33 primes.  OpenSCAD code is provided; changing a single parameter in tower_2.scad chooses other sets of prime numbers.

I designed these mounts so that I could mount a pair of 120mm fans I had to my mendel.  You can use the mounts to fit most standard computer fans to M8 or 5/16" threaded rod.
I just use mine as a snap fit, but there are holes in the part that allow you to clamp them down on the rod using M4 nuts and bolts.
Feel free to make requests for modifications

Print one of  fan mount A, and one of fan mount B.  If you are trying to mount two fans across your Mendel then you will need a support block in between them.
I have included the block that I used for my fans (38mm thick fans) in addition to an external link that can be used for any standard computer fan.  When I get a chance I will add the files for 25mm fans.
Gond de porte de douche

This is a case to protect the wonderful little LC100 sub $40 inductance and capacitance meter. Upper and lower case halves snap together. Solidworks source files and Ultimaker profile settings are included. Modify however you would like.

Made with a 0.4 mm diameter nozzle and black 4043D PLA. Layer height 0.09 mm, wall thickness 0.85 mm and 20% fill. Temperature 227 C, cooling fan off and be sure to check your machine is not under extruding. The catches need to be fused together well so they don't snap off. The upper case needs to be supported. The line support setting worked well in Cura 14.09, really easy to remove.  
If you want to edit the solidworks design: Top is the top assembly that was used to create Case. Case got split into upper case and lower case. The detail features are added within upper case and lower case.

remixed_from.author: gpvillamil
remixed_from.title: Parametric knob for attaching camera to $14 Steadicam

description.text:
I really love the camera sliders that are built with extruded aluminum.  Most of the ones I've seen are part of larger, more complicated designs, meant to be belt driven or requiring special hardware.
Having leftover aluminum pieces from a build, I designed this simple bracket to mount the piece to a surface.
This is not for steady video dolly-style effects.  This is really just to be able to change one axis for a still camera.

description.header:
Parts list:
1 x Piece of 80/20's 1010 extrusion (or anything else with 1"x1" dims)
product link: www.8020.net/1010-Pop-Up.htm
2 x RB_CamMount_EndCap
2 x knob_one_quarter_inch.stl
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7979 (Thanks gpvillamil)
1 x 1/4"-20 Round/Pan Headed Bolt. Mine is 1" length, but up to you.
2 x 1/4"-20 Nuts
2 x 4-40 machine screws (feel free to use your M3 hardware)
2 x 4-40 nuts
Optional quick-release camera mount (Mine was $12-15 at NYC camera shop)
description.text:
Push the brackets into the channels of each end of the aluminum.
Mount to desired surface with 4-40 hardware. Force fit nuts into each knob.
Put both knobs onto bolt. Thread bolt with knobs into camera (if you're using quick release, it should thread into that).
Tighten knob against the camera/quick-release, to keep it snug. Slide your camera assembly (camera/quickrelease/bolt&knobs) intro track to desired position.
*Note: Second knob needs to be spaced far enough away from bolt head to fit into aluminum track. Once you get it to the desired place, tighten the bottom knob against the aluminum. Viola! Super simple sliding camera mount. Note: If you need to cut your piece of extruded aluminum to size (I used 80/20's 1010 model, which is 1" x 1" cross-section). I have a metal blade for my chop saw. You can use a hacksaw, or a dremel/grinder with a carbide disc.

author: dave86

description.text: These parts replace several metal parts of the T-handles on a ute/pickup canopy.  Mine were damaged, and I've been unable to get replacement handles locally, so these were made as a temporary fix.  The handle and locking mechanism from the original handle are reused.

Print each of the tree parts (on a Replicator I used 2 shells, 50% infill, no raft).  The two outer parts fit face-to-face.  I painted the faces with acetone to weld them together, but they are under compression, so the weld is just to keep things aligned.
This is intended to be a temporary solution until I can find replacement handles, but nothing is so temporary as a permanent fix.
The outer bracket has a slot that interacts with a pin on the metal shaft to limit the rotation to 90 degrees.  I did not include a hole to accommodate the locking pin, so the key lock cannot be used.
There is a single scad file that produces both of the outer parts.  Set the variable showTop to true to print the top part, or to false to print the bottom part.

This is an insert for a muffler that I put on my honda. I didn't realize when I bought the muffler how deep the tones would be due to the size of the in/out. This presses inside of a 2" ID muffler pipe and gives me some extra back pressure while reducing noise. Because of the other exhaust changes I've made, this makes the car run almost as if it were stock, but it saved me almost 200 dollars for the 'OEM' muffler / exhaust setup. It also ensures the exhaust exits the back of the car, so I don't get any in the cab as well as shooting far enough to clear the garage door (just a foot or two) so it doesn't fill up the garage when the car is warming up. I did some looking and my own crude tests and it seems that the car doesn't get hot enough at the exhaust tip to cause the abs to melt. However I haven't tried this in the summer yet, as its winter where I'm at. This car isn't worth much money so thus why I was trying to rig something up. Sadly the first version I tried of this printed very well, however I didn't secure it with any kind of screws in the tailpipe (pressure fit only) and it happened to pop out while driving. Next install will utilize some zip screws or stainless pin to keep in place. Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280483 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=280483

I printed this at .3mm layer height, with concentric patterns. Print went very well (about 45 minutes). I used my hands and a little force to slip this inside the muffler tip and tried to get it in far enough that the sun wouldn't directly shine on it all the time (my abs isn't uv resistant). Car started and runs fine. One note of caution, do not make your hole too small. I tried to get this back to the approximate size of the stock exhaust and I might be slightly under that. I take no responsibility if you mess your car up - mine isn't worth really any money so I play around with it. I wouldn't do this to anything nice, don't be a cheap ass and buy the metal exhaust pieces. Using the following options in customizer: pct = .60
Rthroat = 15
minRadius = 4
Aout = 45
Ain = 20
Rexit = 1
Rinlet = 25
wallThickness = 4

author: LizHavlin

description.text: Element charnière porte de cuisine

The propeller for my Bison electric outboard motor was getting a bit beaten up looking so I thought I'd have a go at making one with the 3d printer and 123D Design CAD software.
It's not an exact copy of the original but pretty close and fits very well.
It might also fit other makes of outboard as I've seen others with very similar looking props. Update 8/7/2016 :- Firtsly, apologies for taking so long to provide an update for this.
After testing version 1 on water, it turned out to be a little under powered due to the blades being too thin so I've made another version of the blades which are slightly thicker and so more rigid providing better thrust.
I've also produced a third version which can be printed as one whole piece if you have a 200x200mm bed.
This version was made with the same center piece (or prop head) I drew with CAD software but the blades were produced using a 3D scanner to scan the original blades. The 3D scan is extremely accurate so the blades on this version are pretty much a perfect copy of the Bison prop blades.
The blades were then merged with the center piece in 123D Design to produce a final STL file of the whole prop.
If you attempt to print this version, you will of course need supports and I'd recomment at least 20% infill.
I did try scanning the whole prop but there was a bit too much detail in the center piece to get a usable model. Update 16/8/2016 :- Some minor tweaking of the whole prop version to get a better fit and less friction.
I would recommend this version if you have a large enough build plate as it is the closest to the original prop and provides much better thrust.

comments.text:
Hi,
Nice design, I printed all the separate parts, however it won't fit.
The slit in the head is too small for the blade to slide in. Slit is 3mm and blade is 5mm.
Because I thought I had too much support material that I couldn't remove, but it came out exactly the same.
I saw that you posted here an update version with thicker blades.
So is it possible that the old head.stl is uploaded with the new blade_v2.stl and therefore has a smaller slit?
comments.author: gizmo86the2nd

comments.text:
Hi, thanks for pointing this out. I've checked the CAD drawing, the new blade and the gap in the head are both 4mm so I'm not sure what happened there ?? Could be that I exported the wrong CAD files to STL ??
To be safe, I've uploaded both the new head and blade versions again. Apologies for any inconvenience caused.
If your printer has a big enough build size, I would strongly recommend printing the one piece version, "whole_prop". This version is much closer to the original prop and performs much better than the 3 piece version.
comments.author: gizmo86the2nd

comments.text:
Had a chance to try out the new one piece version "whole prop" last night while out fishing.
Works pretty well but there's some vibration from it, not sure why as it's almost identical to the real prop ??
I'll keep working on this but for now, this is still a good backup prop and will get you home in an emergency.
comments.author: scobo

comments.text:
Just printed the new "whole prop" version, quite pleased with it.
Picture here ..... http://www.thingiverse.com/make:237587
comments.author: scobo

comments.text:
Ok, I had a chance to try the V2 blades yesterday and they're much better.
There's much better thrust from them but I'm still not quite 100% happy with them. There seems to be a fair bit of vibration compared to the original Bison prop, I think maybe the blades are a bit too long.
Hopefully, the latest version "whole prop" will address this although V2 is still fine as a spare or backup prop.

I've made a new version with slightly thicker blades which should make them more rigid.
I'll post an update once I've tried the new version.

title: Clip for mounting IKEA RGB led set

description.text:
Mounting clip for mounting IKEA RGB led set to Velleman Vertex K8400.  
No hardware modifications needed! :)  
IKEA RGB led light set article number: 401.923.61

Just push the thin flange into the positioning hole of the Vertex frame all the way to the corner. It should stay there nicely!
Then just push the led strip in the clip. Check the print orientation! 2 per light strip are needed. Total of 8 pieces. Print one first to check the fit!!

comments.text:
These clips snap very nicely to the ikea light strips.
But how do they tight together with the k8400.
The slips without holes are glued ?
comments.author: gigl

comments.text:
They are very tight in my Vertex. I have had no problems with the clips staying in place without any glue and I am not afraid of them slipping.
Manufacturing variations may however affect how tight they are and thus you need to judge it by yourself whether glue is needed or not.

description.text: This is a box I made to house a small microphone amplifier circuit I purchased on eBay from udani32.

I printed this in PLA with a stock Replicator 2. Print both sides with the flat side down. A standard High setting with .15mm layer height, supports and 15% infill should work fine. I strongly recommend a raft when printing boxes to prevent warping. See the attached profile for a raft that is easier to remove than the rafts provided in the stock profiles. Purchase a male and female XLR jack like this one Assemble the circuit board per the instructions. Insert into the bottom piece so that board rests in the pegs. Insert a 12v power source (I used an old AC adapter) through the provided hole. Solder to the input. Snap the top piece of the box onto the bottom. Press the XLR jacks into the inset holes and use small screws to secure them.

To go with the new multiple-color plotting functionality of my Unicorn G-Code Output extension for Inkscape, here's a new version of the Baltimore Node logo. This one is ready to plot in 2 layers - all of the black parts at once, followed by all of the blue ones, with a pause at the beginning of each layer to allow a pen change. I also made use of my Hershey Fonts in SVG to make the word "baltimore" more readable after plotting. This should make it look nice, for example, on an EggBot. UPDATE! I forgot to resize the original for a sticky note pad (whoops!) and I was right that the EggBot version needed layers beginning with a number. Updated files attached and pictures added! Links
  • Unicorn Inkscape extension: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5986
  • Hershey Fonts in SVG: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6168

If you have a Unicorn, try out the attached G-Code. It's set to start with the pen centered over 0,0 and fits on a sticky note pad (75mm x 75mm).
If you have an EggBot, try plotting the SVG using the Layers dialog. Layer 1 is black, Layer 2 is blue.

title: Dyson Handheld Vacuum Cleaner Adaptor for Ø32mm Tube

description.text:
Disclaimer:
Due to the recent incidents (things appearing on ebay) I just want to make something very clear:
I do not allow any commercial use of my STL-files, my designs and my photos! Description:
Have you ever dreamed about pimping you Dyson Handheld Vacuum Cleaner? Yes, me too! I was not able to reach the ceiling in my flat with my Dyson DC43H handheld vacuum cleaner. And jumping during cleaning was not the solution. So I designed an adaptor to attach a 32mm tube to my cleaner. Now the dust on my ceiling is not safe anymore. And next summer I will clean all the apples on the trees in my garden! No, I am not crazy - I have been tested... EDIT:
While I was vacuuming my ceiling the adaptor cracked into two pieces. Unfotunately one wall was too thin. I corrected this and made the part shorter, too. The extra length is not needed.
The new adaptor can now be downloaded.

comments.text: Well I bought my Dyson a couple months ago at Costco. Great machine unlike every other battery operated unit I have ever owned, BUT I wanted to be able to use it for the floor without bending over. Here it is!! Saw this last night and downloaded it, printed it this morning, used it this afternoon and wow, what an improvement! I printed it in ABS and then did an acetone brush both inside and out to improve the strength.  Great design. Now you need to post an adapter to the brush and crevice tool for the other end of the pipe. Also it fit fine but the first time I inserted it in the vacuum it went in fine but didn't want to remove. I used a small knife to lift the back of the lock a little and it came right out. Sanding lightly the locking edge to give it a slight radius solved the problem and it fits better than the Dyson tools. Thank you very much!!

description.text: testing testing

This is a very exciting print, especially when the sphere starts and ends! This was printed with PLA and no support material. http://www.webmd.com/allergies/sinus-pain-pressure-11/neti-pots Above is a link to what a neti pot is. This design is art deco and ergonomic. The cantilevered reservoir orb is designed to not shift its center of gravity as it pours, thereby giving comfortable balance while in use. It was also designed to be a work of art, and sit out in the open, to start conversations, not hide in a dark closet somewhere.

WARNING This design assumes that the user uses good judgement before putting it in his or her nose. MAKE SURE that the nozzle is free from any pieces of plastic that may break free and become stuck in the nasal passage. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE Thank you. This was my first time experimenting with a 3D CAD program(Rhino version 5) so my scale was a little off. For an appropriately sized (for noses) neti pot, scale it down to between 40-50% of its original size." I suggest slowing the print speed down as it nears the end of the print so the orb closes properly(I find the last 3 minutes of the print to be very exciting). This is a very aggressive design, and although the shape of the orb(sphere) allows for a unusually large over hang, the circle opening of the reservoir makes end of the print very delicate, so watch out! You may want to slow the printer down when the bottom of the orb starts to form on top of the cantilever stem. Overall, I am very happy with this piece and would really like to hear from other printers. Please let me know how it works for you. I really like how the product looks in the clear PLA. REMEMBER TO SCALE THE POT SMALLER! I would appreciate feed back or tips to scale the neti pot in a program, so I can re-post it at the proper size. PLEASE RECYCLE YOUR UNUSED PARTS! Cheers!

comments.text: Just throwing this out there - I wouldn't recommend anyone treat this as more than a single-use neti pot. There have been cases of hospitalization/extreme illness from people using neti pots where bacteria had accumulated around crevices. 3D printed material is generally not food safe due to its very porous nature. It's prone to having bacteria getting gunked up inside the pores.

description.text: Reuleaux polygons are a specific shape families that have the property to have a constant width. You can roll these shapes between 2 rulers and they will stay parallel!

These have the same diameter of 40mm so they should work nicely as a full set with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:61275 You can see a tutorial on how to make the non-regular shapes with inventor here: http://wp.me/p3gI7M-1E Enjoy!

Quadcopter/Hexacopter arm replacement with round shape to reduce resistance for propeller. Designed for 2212 920KV and GF2215/20 motors. Also oval shape helps reduce bending and flipping of arm comparing with flat versions.  
quad_leg_2212 920KV_hole_for_wires_oval version is with added center oval hole 6x4x4 mm size.  
quad_leg_2212 920KV_9_20150111 - version with removed leg and increased resistance of bending in perpendicular direction according motor axis.(Problem is that: When motors with propeller are not balanced correctly there is bending vibrations in perpendicular axis vs. motor axis).

Printed with Green ABS.
Layer Height: 0.2 mm
Nozzle Size: 0.3 mm
Fill pattern: Rectilinear
Fill Density: 30%
Vertical Shells: 3
Horizontal shells Top/Bottom: 3
Total Weight: ~32 g. (Original Weight ~52 g. Dark Red 53 g.)
Printed in 45 angle vs Z axis, because of small heatpad. Thus fill pattern generated with Slic3r is 45 degrees. quad_leg_2212 920KV_hole_for_wires_oval oval hole 6x4x4 mm size printed with green ABS total weight is 31.42 g. Printed with white PLA (30% infill) weight is 33.92 g. Arm printed with PLA seems more flexible than printed with ABS. It bends more easier. with 25% infill PLA arm weight is ~31.2 g. quad_leg_2212 920KV_5x8_wires_hole with larger oval hole for motor wires (Not printed yet). Weak place found ARM leg it can easy broken.. next versions will be with lower but thicker leg. quad_leg_2212 920KV_V201506 - this version is with reduced body thickness and strengthened leg (contact to arm - near motor). (not printed yet) quad_leg_2212 920KV_V201506 i printed with PLA 20% infill rate total weight is 29.79 g. and maintains similar strength comparing with older versions. Thus printed with ABS weight should be around 2-3 g. lower.

description.text: These are two tripod mounts for a GoPro. The bases are sized for a quick-release system and they also have the cut out where you can put a 1/4 inch Nut for a bolt mount.
You will need support material when you print these. I've printed some in ABS using 20 % infill on my UP ! mini without any problems. There can be a lot of support material depending on your slicer.

I modified an old Logitech STX webcam to be a webcam magnefier/microscope and needed a stand to keep a stable picture. This covers parts needed to make the stand. For more information to convert the webcam see: http://hackteria.org/wiki/index.php/DIY_microscopy or google DIY webcam microscope, etc.

My webcam had a 14mm dia plastic shroud that the lens threaded into which I used to mount the camera in the arm. I sanded the opening in the arm with sandpaper so that it was a snug interference fit. NOTE: I had the fit tight and the lens did not thread it! The rest of the parts are leftovers from previous projects or stuff I had around.
(1)Webcam = Logitech Communicate STX
(2)Guide Rails = 8mm linear motion (length as required, mine are 4")
(1)Threaded Rod = M8x1.25 (about an inch longer than rails)
(1) M8x1.25 nut
CA/Super glue may be needed for loose fitting parts. Free Software - I'm using ehe_v2, which is the first link on this page: http://www.oasisscientific.com/downloads.html I included the DWG file because my printer was printing the holes about .4mm small so the holes may need small tweaks to be prefect. A 8mm drill and slightly larger may be handy to ream holes if needed. I printed mine from PLA at .2mm LH and 25% infill. Printed awesome, the whole thing works great for manually populating small SMD components for reflow. I will add a LED light ring when I get a second to design it.

description.text:
Simple model rocket to fly with my son's Estes models.  I lost every rocket design I printed before and didn't like the motor retention methods on other models so I sat down and made this.  It has a quick mount for the motor and plenty of room for a parachute and wadding.  
Can work with Class C or D model rocket engines from Estes.  Just print the appropriate type motor and block parts.  
Will post an update after launching this rocket.  
Also working on an Army Men delivery system...

I made mine with the minimal parts which was about 18 inches high. You can add mid-sections to make it longer but I don't know at what point that would be unstable. The basic assembly requires: One of each part except:
  • Print the appropriate motor and block type (C or D)
  • 2 tie-down inserts (couplings)
  • 4 fins
    For additional length, print an extra tie-down insert and payload section, or two, or three, how tall can you go?... The extension has the rod guide but is otherwise the same as the payload section. Bad naming convention here...
    • Assembly: Dry fit all parts first. Some sanding/razor work might be in order depending on your printer.

  • Place a rocket engine into the Motor Type C/D and insert into the Rocket Base. Slide the Motor Block with the tapered side down into the tube of the rocket base until it firmly holds the engine centered in the tube. Apply a glue to the block to hold it in place. I use a liquid Acrylic glue applied with a needle.

  • Slide the fins into the guides on the rocket base section and glue them in place.

  • Glue a tie-down insert into the top the rocket base. Then add and glue the extension/payload section. Then glue another tie-down and secure a shock cord to the tiedown that is at least three times the length of this section (or 300mm). Then glue down the next extension/payload section with the shock cord going through the center.

  • Tie the other end of the shock cord to the nose cone tie-down. Also tie off the parachute to the nose cone tie-down. Then secure the tie-down to the nose cone with a screw or glue or both. Pack wadding and the parachute into the last extension/payload section and secure the nosecone (no glue here, duh).
    • Refer to photos...

remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: Robust and precise NEMA 17 steppers / belt tensioners

description.text:
This is a remix of Mooncactus' and Jelle's Ultimaker Original short belt tensioner. I've moved it to the inside of the machine, with a full spacing of 11mm (someone replaced my wooden spacer with 10mm plastic spacers which wore away at the belt). For fitting the parts to the printer you'll need four extra M3 bolts:
2x M3x16 (pull bolt)
2x M3x10 (through wall)
I used 4 rings and didn't fit a spring, see attached pictures. There's one caveat: you'll need to saw a slot in the back of your machine to allow the y+ endstop cable to pass through (I didnt want mine pushing against the stepper motor).

I printed the part with supports, but with proper bridging it should print without.
Settings: I printed with 2mm walls, top and bottom, 20% fill.

This is my first attempt at a gripper design. I will be making changes as I find problems with the design. I am using a standard Hi Tec servo for a template. Also, I will be adding different left and right gripper designs as I need them. The current grippers are designed for adhesive weather strip foam affixed to each side. The small holes can be tapped out with 4-40 or a 3M .5 tap depending. I used 4-40 3/8" and 1/2" cap screws. Here is a link to alternate grippers for this assembly. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:621809 Here is the link to the Rob Gripper top plate http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:622861

Most of what you need to know is in the pictures I posted with the STL files. I used 4-40 cap screws 1/2" and 3/8 " long. The disc and screws that the drive gear connects with came in the servo box. When I printed the parts I used .4mm 1st layer and .2mm for the rest. I also printed this out in PLA but plan on doing all parts in ABS. For a better fit on the joints pins instead of the 4-40 screws will give a smoother operation but the hole would need drilled out for the pins.

title: Belt tensioner for Prusa I3 X axis

description.text:
This belt tensioner fits into the open side of the right part of the X gantry of the Prusa I3 reworked set.
I am still overworking this design, but it is already functional.
Additional parts:
1 x M4 nut
1 x M4 screw 30 - 40 mm.
The belt will slide over the rounded part of the belt tensioner. I used PLA and the belt really slides very well without any noticeable force.
However I will redesign everything over time and also try IGUS special filament with ultralow friction in a second version.
Also check out: http://3dptb.blogspot.com/2015/01/riemenspanner-fur-prusa-i3-x-achse.html

Used PLA. maybe better than ABs because of the higher friction of ABS.
Printer settings: Fine parts, 100% infill (would work with 10% infill as well, but parts are rather small, so ..)

author: fractalnoise

title: Spool Holder for 10lb, 5lB, 2lb and 0.5lb spools using skateboard bearings as a "lazy susan"

description.text:
I have been trying to think of an easy way to keep the 3D printer fed without using motors and to also not have tangles. This method keeps tension off of the printer head and does not tangle the filament. Using skateboard bearings was the key since they spin very nice with a heavy spool on them. There's two pieces to this design, the base "table side" and the "spool side" holder. It uses any standard skateboard bearing which is tapped into the spool holder. I printed the spool holder with 50% fill to make it strong so hammering the bearing in does not crack it. The base has four screw holes to mount it to a board. This works with the 10 pound spools and I can make adapters for other spools if people request. The "Spool_side_12-25-2014.STL" is for the 1 inch hole spools (10 pounders) and the "Spool_side_2_inch 1-5-2015.STL" is for the standard Makerbot ones. I would be happy to make more sizes if people request. Just ask. :) http://youtu.be/hhQFurWS7i4
http://youtu.be/xo1MFLBwyD8 Standard bearings: http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss_1/189-4144984-6479618?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=skateboard+bearings

For the spool side, use 50% fill to make it strong.  That way the bearing will not split the plastic when tapping it into the plastic.  Tap gently to get it flat into the holder.  I print the spool holder upside down using supports.  Then you can tap the skateboard bearing in using a decent sized hammer.  It is tight on purpose so it does not pop out.

I also feed the machine from above and have my spools on a wire rack like this: http://www.amazon.com/Whitmor-6070-322-Supreme-4-Tier-Shelving/dp/B000LRFG60/ref=sr_1_4?s=storageorganization&ie=UTF8&qid=1421097282&sr=1-4&keywords=wire+rack

description.text: UPDATE: Don't bother printing this thing for flight. Epic fail in video at: http://youtu.be/27vNgNWPca4. Turns out to be way to heavy for the Type C motor and I don't think the Type D would have helped either. I'm going to redesign this for fewer paratroopers and try a Type D next time... I was originally designing this for the little green Army paratroopers but the local store only had these animals. Designed to launch and deploy 12 parachute creatures. This contraption mounts on the earlier rocket base and was included in the files. If you want to recover all the para-men, you should probably use the Type C motors unless you have a a very large area for recovery. Also, I'm loading these guys with the parachutes outward to minimize friction with the outer sleeve. The fit was a bit tighter then I expected. Will post the first-flight results when the weather clears.

• Print all the parts, two of the Carriers.

  • Tie off a shock cord (three times the length of the tube) to the nose cone and glue the nose cone to the tube.

  • Glue up the Base, carriers, and carrier cap. Test fit the tube.

  • Tie off the lanyard to one hole of the carrier cap. And tie off the parachute to the other hole in the cap.

  • Place a rocket engine into the Motor Type C/D and insert into the Rocket Base. Slide the Motor Block with the tapered side down into the tube of the rocket base until it firmly holds the engine centered in the tube. Apply a glue to the block to hold it in place. I use a liquid Acrylic glue applied with a needle.

  • Glue the rocket base to the army men base using the tie-down insert as a coupling.
    • Refer to pictures...

The "best" and least expensive way to test the thrust to weight ratio of your rocket and motor would be to employ a rocketry simulation software.  I personally use RockSim from Apogee Components, but there are many others.  In fact, if you would like to collaborate with me, since I have access to the software, don't hesitate to shoot me an email.  I will be getting my own 3-d printer within a month or two. This plastic clip protects the wires that attach to the print head on the Printrbot simple metal. It attaches to the Y-arm, right over the fan and holds the wires away form the other moving parts. It can prevent the wires from: 1) getting pinched between the extruder motor and the Y axis motor.
2) jamming the Y axis causing belt-grinding or misprints.
3) internally breaking from repeated bending near the motor. Issue 1 and 2 happened to be repeatedly. Issue 3 was a problem my friend had after running a printer for a year. It was a difficult problem to find and fix.

1) Print out the file.
2) Remove the top 2 bolts from the fan mount which is set in the side of the Y-arm.
3) Place the clip over the mount holes so the clip's holes line up with them.
4) replace the bots so that they hold the clip and the fan in place.
5) take the wires (which are bound inside the tubular wire holder) and pop them into the round end of the clip.
6) Use a small zip tie to hold the wires in place.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Extruder Stabiliser & Cable Chain Mount

description.text:
This is a remix of the extruder cable chain mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:514728), and the Bottom Link of the Open Cable Chain. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40918) Both of the mounts presented here have been modified to make them fit on the Simple Metal's base and extruder. I had to tweak my y axis stop, resulting in the loss of a couple mm from the print bed's volume, otherwise homing the Y axis will result in the printer grinding as it tries to compact the chain down. YMMV. Edit:
I've uploaded a newer version of the extruder mount to accommodate the cable exit if you've managed to do what I did and strip out the screw that the bearing screws into, forcing you to rotate the extruder motor to get a 'fresh' hole. :) I also added the mounts for the Y axis harness; the motor side I went lo-tech/low-rent on; You'll need either a pair of zip ties or a really long skinny tie that will wrap around the motor. the lower mount has a plate that lines up with the a screw hole in the base; You'll need a screw that fits it to secure it. Edit, 2/28/2015: Removed the 'work in progress' flag; I've been running with the current versions now for a couple months, and it's been solid.

To use these, print them out at the same settings as the chain.  the extruder side is a press fit. The base side screws into one of the Z rod tower holes and straddles the cable opening.   
For the Y axis harness, the motor side mount will require one or two zip ties, depending on length; it simply zip ties to the motor and hangs out. (see pictures)

comments.author: senorbanana

comments.text: It may vary depending on your specific printer. For my simple metal, I printed one each of the bases. (extruder motor, Y axis motor, and the two bases). These are remixed from the Open Cable Chain (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40918), of which I printed for the print head chain 6 pairs of the 45-A/B links, and 3 pairs of the normal A/B links. two of those pairs are on the base side of the chain, and the third is on the extruder side. If you look at the feature picture you can see exactly how I put it together. the Y axis chain I probably could have put it together differently, but it works ok all the way to the top of the Z axis travel. It's composed of 5 pairs of the 45-A/B links and another 3 pairs of the normal A/B links, with two pairs off from the lower base and the third pair off from the Y motor base. the remaining 45-x links connect the two ends.

TBH, It takes the Y-axis  from the full 150mm to about 140-ish, so for me at least it's not a huge loss. I haven't had the need to run a full 150 by 150 object on my printer, and truth be told, it'd probably turn out really bad from warping due to the unheated bed.  Feel free to re-mix the part and experiment; that's what I did to make the original part (which was for the wooden kits) work on the metal.

title: Hole Plugs for Da Vinci Printers

description.text: These plugs fill the holes in the interior floor of the XYZPrinting Da Vinci 1.0 / 1.0A / 2.0 printer, to prevent objects falling inside. Variations of the plugs themselves have holes in them, to store your UHU glue stick, brush and cutters (Hakko CHP-170 Micro Soft Wire Cutter - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FZPDG1K )!

• Dimensions: 1.496"W x 1.496"L x 0.787"H (each)
  • Volume: 0.39-0.53 cubic inches (each, with base plate)
  • Weight: ~0.02 pounds (each, with base plate)

• Set (2 blank, 1 glue stick, 1 tools): PTW-00-1-PT-0190-XXX (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A, Set).STL
  • Plug without hole: PTW-00-1-PT-0190-000 (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A).STL
  • Plug with glue stick hole only: PTW-00-1-PT-0190-001 (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A, Glue).STL
  • Glue stick base plate only: PTW-00-1-PT-0190-002 (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A, Glue Base).STL
  • Plug with tool holes only: PTW-00-1-PT-0190-003 (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A, ToolA).STL
  • Tools base plate only: PTW-00-1-PT-0190-004 (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A, ToolABase).STL
    • (.STL names do not match .SLDPRT name because Da Vinci will not print file names over 56 characters.) Based on the idea, but not the files from, this part: http://us.gallery.xyzprinting.com/us_en/membergallery/model/201407092113577

• Print the set of plugs, and base plates. File PTW-00-1-PT-0190-XXX (Plug, DaVinci 1.0A, Set).STL includes all 4 plugs. Required ~13m of filament, to print at 0.1 layer height, excellent quality, on my machine.
  • Test fit the base plates in the bottom of the plugs, trim edges by scraping with a razor knife if necessary.
  • Glue the base plate in the bottom of the plug, with acetone for ABS, or other appropriate cement or glue.
  • Install the plugs in the interior floor holes of the printer. The press-fit ribs are intentionally oversized slightly. Scrape the ribs lightly with a razor knife, or use a file, to adjust for snug fit. The tools plug works best in the front left corner, with the hole with rounded corners in the corner of the machine.
  • Place UHU glue stick and tools in holes in plugs.

comments.text: I actually lost the belt tensioner wheel inside the floor of my 3D printer. After turning the printer upside down, I was able to get it out. These plugs are kinda important! If you don't feel like printing it, you can always tape the holes as well

title: Solar panel terminal box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Placed on the back of the solar panel this box gives you somewhere to connect your external wiring to each panel and add a diode etc as required.
I am currently experimenting with making my own solar panels as cheaply as possible and the commercially available terminal boxes are very expensive for what they are. I have placed a number of hole options in this box and will revise the number and position of these as my solar panel project proceeds.
Uses 2 x 12mm long M4 machine screws for terminals and 1 x 20mm long M4 machine screw to hold the lid on.

Print it out.
Clear out the 4mm holes with a 4mm drill bit.
Fit three x M4 nuts in the central nut chamber (sounds like my workshop).
Fit 2 x 12mm long M4 machine screws and washers on the two outside holes for the terminal screws.
Fit the lid with a 20mm long M4 machine screw to hold it on. I may change these machine screw sizes when it finishes printing, and I will probably make a larger version of this once I have worked out hw to make it all work.

comments.text: Added a second version TB2 which has captive nuts and machine screws. I have increased the gaps for the lid so hopefully this one will fit together better. I'll make it bigger once the parts are proven to fit together properly.

comments.text: Solar has got to be the way to go. I am using individual cells sourced from China and making them into 18 volt 140 Watt panels. My first array will be 3 of panels into a couple of deep cycle batteries and directly run a 2-3kW hot water system (boiler) for normal domestic usage. I am hoping to get enough energy during the day to run the system entirely from the solar but we'll see.

friends are looking for a cake topper so just playing around with some things.

After doing a fair amount of experimenting with mini-quads over the past year or so, I have found that the 250 size carbon fiber mini-quads that have become ever popular in the RC community, are just a tad bit too small to comfortably fit all of the electronics on-board the craft. They are also lacking some features I think are key. So I decided to design my own fully 3D Printed mini-quad with features that I have wanted/ needed. Like a holder for the male end of the power cable so it’s not floating around in danger of being cut by the propellers; happened to me.... Also some frames don’t allow enough space to easily slide a video transmitter between the standoffs. My goal with this project was to build the cleanest, most streamlined, yet functional mini-quad I could design. It’s my first design with a bit of tweaking but I’m sure it could be better. So if you have any suggestions please feel free to leave them in the comments! This is just a proof of concept, it’s not the final product. I would like to have it machined out of carbon fiber and have it mass produced with a PDB board with LED’s in the future. If you or someone you know has the equipment to CNC carbon fiber frames in mass, please let me know. The quad is designed around the RC Timer mini-quad power system you can buy all in one on their website, which provides plenty of power for this frame. Also the frame is designed to hold any mini flight controller mounted dead center with 30.5mm hole spacing; Naze32, CC3D, KK Mini ect… I personally prefer the KK Mini because it is so easy to setup and tune right on the quad. I highly recommend NOT using CPPM for any RC setup UNLESS YOU KNOW HOW IT WORKS, and KNOW WHAT YOU ARE DOING. Some of people crash because CPPM is biased on electrical pulses and if you use too many channels you can confuse the board if the initial sync pulse becomes too small. Your control inputs can get mixed up and you will crash. However I do recommend using the “Hobby King Super Clean RC Male to Male Extension” for connecting your receiver to the board. I use it on all my multirotors, it’s clean and looks good. For the video system it is designed to be used with the Mobius action camera (I use the Mobius wide) I also use the Immersion RC 600mw 5.8GHz transmitter and the Immersion RC circularly polarized antennas. I also integrated an anti-vibration mount for the Mobius. Yes most mini-quads have something similar but this is a mount that is designed to use earplugs instead of the rubber isolation balls that don’t work at all… And not any foam earplugs will do, some are hard and stiff. I use the SUPER SOFT 3M earplugs. They are the consistency of a marshmallow. There is literally ZERO jello in the video. Also I like something to land on other than just the bolts sticking off on the frame, it can gouge them up and chew up the threads if you land on concrete too much. So I designed some landing feet that give it just over ¼” of ground clearance. They simply press fit onto the nuts that secure the arms. I used a hammer to tap them on. Also the nice thing is if you have to change an arm, you can just take out the screws and the nuts will stay in the landing foot and you won’t have to worry about losing them. I’ll put some products links below and list the hardware I used for the project. I used the standoffs from my ZMR 250 frame. Print parts at specified infill and pattern.
  • Top Plate: 50%, Hexagonal, 2 Shells
  • Bottom and Middle plate: 50%, Hexagonal, 2 shells
  • Arms: 80%, Hexagonal, 4 Shells
  • Landing feet: 25%, Linear, 2 Shells
    • Hardware:
  • X20: M3x25mm Screws
  • X20:M3 Lock-nuts
  • X16: M3x15mm Screws
  • X8: M3 Standoffs
    • Accessories and Power System:

  • M3 Standoffs
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/M3-35mm-Round-Aluminum-alloy-Standoff-Spacer-Stud-Fastener-10PCS-aluminum-column-/151456195001?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item23437e21b9

  • Hobby King Super Clean RC Male to Male Extension
    http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__64626__HobbyKing_Super_Clean_RC_Male_to_Male

  • Power System
    http://rctimer.com/product-1131.html

  • Flight Controller (KK Mini)

description.text: This is an extension of the pi cookie cutter from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28882 that allows you to generate cookie cutters with any text.

This script won't work in the Customizer, since it requires the text() module only available in OpenSCAD 2014.QX or later. Open the script in OpenSCAD, update the variables at the top (specifically cutter_text), and save your generated STL. Letters with holes won't work. Sorry. I only needed H, J, G, S, and E. The script could be modified to add a solid back to the cutter, but that makes it harder to remove dough if it gets stuck in the middle.

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: bilid

comments.text: The latest version of OpenSCAD appears to have text() support, so you should be fine downloading that from the OpenSCAD homepage.

author: sagitaire12

description.text:
Use this anytime you need a small hollow box or tray of specific dimensions and wall thickness . For example, this happened to me recently:  
"It is dinner time and I hear a shriek coming from the kitchen. It's my wife spilling uncooked pasta all over and blaming me because I supposedly put the box away backwards."   
If you are married you probably understand. Exactly why I got a 3D printer. Simple solution: print a box end. Volia... No more pasta spills at dinner time and I don't have to worry about putting the pasta box away backwards.  
You can probably come up with other uses for this simple box. It is fully customizable. I hope you find it useful.  
Rev A: Changed slider bars to input boxes for an improved user experience in Customizer.

Use customizer to set the dimensions you need. Its easy!  
Set end thickness to 0 to make a hollow beam or rectangular tube with no floor.  
Print without support. 0.2 mm layer works well.

comments.text: Thanks for this time-saving parametric!  My first use was to make end caps for LED strip lights that I use outside.  The strips themselves have a silicon like covering except for the ends if you cut the strips (which I always do).  You can purchase end caps, but, if you don't already have them, the postage becomes outrageous.

Allows Zeepro Zim to hold more filament than its physical size would appear to allow. You can utilize full 1Kg spools, along with smaller 1lb rolls. Requires removing a couple of parts, and will effectively bypass the cartridge mechanism.

What you'll need for dual spools:
11/64" drill bit.
5/32" drill bit.
2x 3/4" #8 machine screws.
2x #8 lock nut.
2x 5/8" metal screws.
2x ~1.5' PTFE teflon tubing 4mm OD X 2mm ID.
2 sets of these parts. Fast preset works fine for this. There are a couple of overhangs on the hook bracket, so be sure support is enabled if using some other preset. The holes are intentionally slightly smaller than needed so that they can be drilled out for a more accurate fit. None of the screws are tighened all the way, just snug but where the arms still move freely as the head moves.

  • Drill both holes in the longer (50mm) arm with a 11/64" drill bit. This will allow a #8 machine screw joining the arms to move freely.

  • Drill the holes in the top of the large back hook bracket with 5/32" bit. Note it is not required to drill this all the way through assuming a shorter screw is used. A 5/8" #8 sheet metal screw can be used here to connect the long arm to the back plate.

  • Drill one hole in the shorter (30mm) arm with 11/64", and the other with 5/32". The smaller hole is to accept the
    PTFE teflon tube with a friction fit. It should be tight. The larger hole is for the #8 machine screw that connects to the long arm.

  • See pictures and assemble the bracket arm as shown. First slide the spool holder down the hook bracket. Push it onto the tab at the bottom until it snaps into place. Be sure the spool holder is on the correct side. It is a tight fit and may break attempting to removing the spool holder once it is snapped into place.

  • Use a 5/8" #8 sheet metal screw for the longer arm attachment to the spool holder plate, and work this slowly to create threads. The PLA is weakest at the hooks where this holes are, forcing the screw may crack the PLA. Go slowly. Leave the screw slightly loose such that the long arm moves freely.

  • Use the 3/4" #8 machine screw and locknut to hold the short arm to the long arm. The short arm had a larger hole and a smaller hole. Use the large one, and leave the lock nut slightly loose such that the small arm moves freely.

  • Remove the teflon tube from the extruder by pressing on the compression fitting black ring and pulling it out. See the zim support website FAQ on removing/replacing teflon tubes for more information if needed.

  • Press fit the new teflon tube into the smaller hole you made on the shorter (30mm) arm. It should be a tight fit. It doesn't have to go all the way through, just fit in enough such that it is snug. There will be a slight amount of tension and compression on this fitting during operation.

  • Insert the other end of the teflon tube in the extruder on the appropriate side. It should be inserted 27.5 mm (see zim support FAQ on removing/replacing teflon tube if needed).

  • Unplug the lower stepper filament micro-switches (disconnect the connectors). This makes the Zim think there is filament in the tube. Thanks to Scientist for this tip! Also you can remove the black plastic shield that forces the wiring harness and original PTFE tubing down the back if you like. It seems to allow the red/black wiring bundle to move freely and reduce stress (see pictures). This piece is only held in by some double stick tape and is not attached to the gantry, despite what it may appear when you first tug on it. You can always put it back in if you miss it.

  • That's it, ready to load and prime. Repeat for the other side once you've tested out one extruder.
    • Loading and Priming:
    You may actually find this easier than the original loading procedure, but it requires feeding the filament into the extruder stepper by hand. Fortunately the filament is easy to feed now with a very short length of PTFE tubing and direct access to the spools.

  • Ensure you have a refillable spool in a cartridge holder, or simply the back plate from a cartridge (see this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611463 to make a clip for a cartridge base plate).

  • Push filament most of the way through the tube to the extruder, but not into the extruder head yet.

  • Select "prime" from the manage my Zim cartridge menu. The "load" option will be missing because we bypassed the microswitch down in the lower compartment, so the Zim will think the filament is already loaded. Once the extruder is heated and the extruder starts to feed, push the filament the rest of the way so it grabs in the extruder. You should see it start extruding, done!

  • Print as usual. You have about 4-5 times as much filament as a stock Zim cartridge when using a single 1Kg spool. You may want to go to the http://zim/cartridge/left or http://zim/cartridge/right menu and set the filament color and start length. The Zim software only allows setting this value up to 200 meters. There is about 400 meters on a 1Kg spool of 1.75mm filament. You will have to reset it at the halfway point to track to last 200 meters. When swapping spools, I usually jot down the approximate amount left on the side of the spool so I can reset it when I reload that spool.

  • Unloading is as easy as loading, but again requires a bit of manual intervention. Select unload, wait for the extruder to heat up and go through it's extrude cycle, and then gently tug on the filament while the extruder stepper withdraws the filament. Once it moves freely, you can pull it the rest of the way.

description.text:
This is an awesome name plate design I have built. It's an easy project. Make sure to read the instructions though. I will post a picture of the one I actually made when I get a chance (it's on my desk at work). Key Features:
  • Editable 123dDesign File included
  • Looks awesome
  • Uses electrical conduit pipe (super cheap) 1/2 inch
  • Easily adaptable to use copper pipe as well
    • Instuctions:
  • Print connectors first
  • Then edit the nameplate file with your name
  • You can use your preferred design program - the dimensions of the name plate itself are 40mm x 280mm x 2mm.
  • Check the length on the nameplate default is 280 mm
  • Cut your pipe lengths about 20mm longer than the nameplate
  • Put it together and finish with the endcaps
    • Tips and Tricks:
  • Buy a pipe cutter, they are like 9 bucks and you can use it on all sorts of projects. A pipe cutter is a small tool you clamp down then just rotate around the pipe. They're awesome.
  • The way I did the nameplate is print it in white, then spray paint it flat black. Then sand the paint off of the letters with a sanding block.
  • I will post a picture of mine when I get a chance. It's on my desk at work. Looks awesome and pretty easy project.
    • Let me know if you have any questions. Best place to get a hold of me is on the free forum on my website. CommandoDesigns.com Thanks for the awesome feedback. Tony D.

author: KevMacD

description.text:
3D printing Rapid prototyping
<a href="http://esfvision.com/

I've slowly but surely been working on an Arduino-based trivia buzzer system (think Jeopardy). The handheld buzzers are made from 3/4" thin-walled PVC, and the wires for the switch and LEDs are connected to a keystone jack, which is at the bottom of the buzzer. Credit to jsadusk for the keystone mounting plate (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6647), which I added to an endcap I designed in OpenSCAD (file included). For best results, flip the model 180 degrees about the X or Y axis so the flat part prints down. The keystone jack I'm using is a CAT 3 one from Home Depot, which just barely fits into the shaft of the PVC pipe. Marked as a work in progress because I still want to round off the edges at the top and bottom, and because my OpenSCAD code is very sloppy. But as you can see, it does work. I included a version that was fixed (keystone_pvc_fixed.stl) for it being non-manifold, though the original file sliced and printed fine on my Printrbot.
You may need to cut or sand the inner edges of the keystone mounting plate to get the keystone jack in.  I had to for mine, but my Printrbot isn't calibrated quite as precisely as I'd like.

title: 250 Quadcopter Multirotor frame for kk2.1 and kk2.0 board

description.text:
All parts can be printed separately on a printer with a build platform that is 5.5" by 5.5" or bigger. It will take about 9 hours in total at .2mm layers. This is a 250 quadcopter frame that i designed based off of other 250 sized quads. This frame is designed around the KK2.1 board sold from HobbyKing for only $20. It may be able to work for other flight controllers. This frame is in multiple parts so it is easy to replace parts after a crash, everything is held together, including the the KK2.1 board and motors (depending on motors) with M3 screws or bolts (M3= 3mm diameter). Each arm is labeled with the according motor spin and each arm will have to be printed twice, along with each landing gear.
  • Required bolts, nuts and washers: x20 M3 (3mm diameter) nuts, x16 M3 washers, x16 M3 25mm in length bolts, x4 M3 10mm in length bolts. (Washers are used for the screws for the motors to hold the screws steadier in their place.
  • The frame has enough clearance for any reasonably sized 3s battery (like 2500) or less.
  • The motor mounts are in a "X" formation an the mounting holes can mount screws that are 14mm apart to 20mm apart (from one screw across to the other screw)...aka any small motor made for 250 quads will fit. Recommended propeller size is 5 inches.
  • There are battery strap holes (2 of them) that passes under the kk2.1 board and holds the battery underneath the main frame.
    • Disclaimer: This has not been printed and tested yet, but it has been assembled electronically and seems to fit fine. I also have built my own 650 multirotor and feel comfortable flying and designing them. If anyone is interested in this print and would be willing to do the first test print, and upload an image on this page for me that would be awesome. At worst, at this stage, you might just have to sand some parts down.

comments.text: Hey just a suggestion, if you were to center the motor pod top to bottom on the arm you would have a universal arm and thus only need 1 spare for any repair if all mount holes are identical. Also the added benefit of a little more prop clearance.

author: harrisonhre

description.text:
I wanted to create a Hearthstone Arena Key with some substance. Something worth holding that would be a mean desktop show piece or trophy.  
I'd modelled up a few of the other keys at approximately realistic key size and found that scaling them up, they didn't quite come out as I'd wanted. So I remodelled the 12 wins key with the intent of having to assemble it, meaning each individual piece would print better and fit together snugly. In addition it would also allow me to hollow out the head of the key and implement LED lighting* to really make it stand out.  
*This is still a work in progress. I have yet to add in the lighting component and 3d modelling work to accommodate the LEDs, power source and switch.

Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2, sliced with Makerware with the following settings: Infill: 15%
Shells: 2
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Temp: 200C - Diamond Age Ivory PLA
with Support* (except the diamonds, they don't need it) The barrel of the key is a piece of Aluminium tubing, 100mm Long x 10mm Diameter.

description.text:
RepRap Discount Full Graphic Display Case with spinner knob and stop button.

All screw holes are 3mm and can accept 4mm long screws.

author: jojofroyo

description.text:
A full-scale replica of a human brain (modeled from an anatomical MRI scan) mounted on a printable stand, featuring LED lights installed within each of the three supports.  
We want to see one printed using glow-in-the-dark filament. If you print one, send pictures.  
If you happen to have an MRI scanner handy, or want to participate in a study at your local university, then it might be easier than you think to print a replica of your own brain instead.
The print is very straightforward. Here's what we did:
Print using standard settings, with a raft, using a dark-colored filament. Print the stand's base upside-down to avoid the need for supports. Print the stand's three supports (the tubes) vertically.

Print using standard settings, with supports and a raft, using natural (clear) filament. Position each hemisphere of the brain with the flat side downward, parallel to the print surface. We printed the brain hemispheres approximately 5mm above the print surface, to make the supports easier to remove.
The brain itself requires a decent amount of filament (and time) to print. Each side requires about 24 hours and 1/2 pound of filament. That's 48+ hours and a pound of filament total.

Here is what you'll need to install the three LED lights. You can buy most of this at RadioShack.
  • Three 5mm LED lights of any color (we used white)
  • Some solid-conductor wire (22 to 26 gauge)
  • 2xAAA battery holder and 2 AAA batteries
  • Basic on/off switch
  • Heat-shrink tubing
  • Solder and soldering iron
  • Super glue
  • Wire cutters and wire strippers

The brain hemispheres are connected using two pairs of neodymium magnets, glued into recesses that were melted into the plastic.  
The battery holder and on/off switch are glued into the compartment on the bottom side of the stand's base. Wires are soldered to form a circuit between the LEDs and the battery holder, with the switch installed to terminate the circuit.

We had a for-fun poker tournament with our friends on Valentine's Day, and I wanted to make a trophy!  
I have uploaded a heart shape that has no engraving, so you can use any 3D software to create a text engraving (2mm deep usually works great).  
I am uploading this nearly 2 years after making it. Back then, I was new to 3D printing, hence the slightly messy text engraving in the picture.

The STLs are already oriented for you.  
THREE OPTIONS for printing:  
OPTION 1: First print the base STL, then without removing it from your build plate, print the Heart. You can change the color of your plastic so the base is one color and the heart is another (this is what I did, although I recall having to use a glue gun or super glue to glue the two pieces together anyway because it may have broken off)  
OPTION 2: Use dual extrusion to print the base as one color and the heart as one color in a single shot.  
OPTION 3: Print the base separately. Then move the heart STL to the build platform and print it separately. Then glue them together!  
Any print resolution you choose should be fine.

University task.  
Response to Ross Lovegrove study.

title: Bracket for LCD screen on Prusa Mendel i3

description.text: Recently built a Prusa Mendel i3, but as built, the LCD screen just hangs on the wire.  Lame.  First non-calibration print, two brackets to hold it in place!

Its pretty obvious from the picture.  Two brackets required.  It is symmetric so two of the same works one for each side.  Use a small screw, and or predrill the hole to clean it out.  I did not follow this advice, used a No 6 wood screw and no predrilling, and one bracket delaminated a bit.

Demande de Mr T****T

This replaces one of the wooden LinnStrument sides with a holder that keeps an iPad in place at a comfortable angle. It accommodates all iPad sizes from the first model to the latest Air, including some iPhones (I tried the 5 and the 6+). Since the LinnStrument can be bus-powered from all iOS devices with a lightning connector, this is a really nice standalone expressive music-making combo. Update 18/01/2015 The holder didn't work with some headphone plugs when using an iPad Air. Made some updates to fix this.

Just print it, support is included, remove the red sections from the screenshots. It fits on the UltiMaker 2's build platform by rotating the middle section 45 degrees.  
Then slide the sides on the middle and screw it onto the LinnStrument's back instead of the wooden side. You can use the same screws, but I didn't use the washer of the middle screw since it sticks out a but too much then, possibly scuffing the iPad.

comments.text: The software in the picture is SampleWiz, it supports 2 out of the 3 axis of the LinnStrument expressiveness.

description.text:
"Do not disturb!" ...Why? "Cause I'm working!"
If you have to say that to everyone who comes by to ask you something. This is something that you might think is useful to have on your desk.
You never have to say a word, Just scroll the sign to the correct phrases and people will know whats up. Combine your own set of phrases that fits your needs with a custom color on the text-infill.
Three changeable phrases on each side, for instance:
On the left Do not disturb! and on the right I'm Printing
Or the left Can't you see? and on the right I'm not HERE!
With a build-in LED fitting for the ones who have to work overtime.
I used the AA "Flexing battery holder" from Enif for powering the LEDs http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900

- UPDATE - Leave in the comments your phrase suggestion! I'll be adding the best suggestions to the phrase plates

title: AIRSOFT MAG ADAPTER NATOMAG - AUGMAG V1.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS HAS BEEN UPDATED http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1478821 I recently purchased a ASG Steyer AUG, but don't like the style of magazine the rifle use. So I googled for a adapter for NATOMAGS or Ar15 mags, but all I could find was someone that have cut his old augmag, and made it into a adapter. I thought allot of AUG users might like such an adapter, so I modeled my own AUGMAG in Inventor, and made it a two part thing, for easier for print.
Maybe someday I would add more options, like Nato to AK, AK to AUG. The lost if BB's will of course rise a bit, since the BB's need to be pushed through the adapter As my previous models, I don't have a 3D printer yet, so the models might be hard to print, or have some scale difficulties, but I have done the best I can with what I have. :-) If you got ideas or stuff I should change please PM me, or leave a comment on the model. And if you are going to print this thing, please send me some pictures! I would really love to see them :-)

You'll need to purchase some things to finish this build.   
The holes for screwing the two parts together are 3.5mm in diameter, this would make a short 4mm screw a good a good choice, feel free to drill the hole bigger or deeper if you have some screws lying around  
For mounting the mag_release you would need a 5mm nut and bolt. And for the spring, its kind of finding a pen with a good spring, or finding something lying around. If enough people ask, I could make it rubberband driven like my Iron Sights.

comments.text: Any idea if this would work for a TM AUG? I am a student at Florida Institute of Technology, so I have access to plenty of printers and CAD software, so I can probably edit it if it doesn't. I was just wondering if you knew? Ill send you some pics/videos if and when I print one.

author: jbr

description.text:
I wanted to build the world's smallest 3D printed Mendocino motor: here it is with my best wishes for 2015 ;-) see it running here: http://youtu.be/PVJAtb6spAQ The Mendocino motor is a solar-powered light commutated magnetically levitated electric motor. The motor consists of a four-sided rotor block in the middle of a shaft. The shaft is positioned horizontally and has a magnet at each end. The magnets on the shaft provide levitation by repelling magnets in a base under the motor.
The rotor block has two sets of windings and a couple of solar cell attached to each winding. When light strikes one of the solar cells, it generates an electric current thus energizing one of the rotor windings. This produces a magnetic field which interacts with the field of the support magnets generating a force perpendicular to the length of the coil (Laplace's law dF = I.dL^B). This interaction causes the rotor to turn. As the rotor rotates, the first solar cell enters shadow and the next solar cell moves into the light and energizes the second winding,
The clever idea is that the second solar cell of each coil is wired in parallel but reverse (+ connected to -) creating a current in the opposite direction to the first thus maintaining the rotation. This process repeats as the motor spins. Electrically a non lighted solar cell acts as a diod this is the reason why they can be wired in reverse-parallel: the non lighted solar cell diode is blocked when the other solar cell is illuminated.
It is then a light-commutated motor !!!

BOM:
  • a ball pen tip
  • 2x12 cm or so of 3 mm carbon shaft tube (from a kite shop) or any wood rod of 3mm
  • 4 solar cell collected from a grasshoper toy (I bought them here: http://www.dx.com/p/novel-solar-powered-locust-30658)
  • a coil of 0.2 mm enamelled copper wire
  • 4 neodymium N42 disk magnets (12 mm diam x 3 mm)
  • 2 neodymium N42 ring magnets (10 mm od x 4 mm in x 4 mm)
    (here is a link for magnets http://www.supermagnete.fr/aimants-anneaux-neodyme/anneau-magnetique-10mm-x-4mm-x-5mm-neodyme-n42-nickele_R-10-04-05-N and http://www.supermagnete.fr/aimants-disques-neodyme-moyens/disque-magnetique-diametre-12mm-hauteur-3mm-neodyme-n45-nickele_S-12-03-N)
    -a 50 mm x 2 mm torch glass lens (http://www.dx.com/p/52mm-x-1-8mm-glass-lens-5948#.VKlc73v-VFs)
    • how to build :
  • with a soldering iron remove the solar-cells from the grasshopers
  • print 5mm in height of the rotor body (mendocino.scad). Try to insert the solar cells, they should slide with some friction and remain in place when the 4th one is inserted. Try to insert the carbon rod in the central hole. You can adjust some parameters in the scad file:
    m = 1.1; // margin added to SC width
    th = 1.01; // wall thickness
    rint = 1.75; // tube radius
    • the wall thickness must be adapted to your printer configuration. To be nice and solid the rotor's wall is composed of 2 filaments printed side by side. With 1.01 mm and using a noozle diameter of 0.5mm coupled with a layer height of 0.2mm; slic3r does the job (see printing video http://youtu.be/nrUyedXopNo) Once printed, insert the shaft inside the rotor, insert the 4 cells (take care of the orientation of the soldering tips that shall be at the extremity !).
    Glue the ball pen tip in the shaft. It's time to wind the coils. Just wind 100 turns of copper wire for each coil. Spread the wires 50 turns on each side of the carbon shaft. Don't forget to keep 8cm or so of free wire at each extremity...
    Gently push 5mm of cell from the rotor this will simplify the welding process. Wire the coils and cell as described on "mendo_principle.jpg" (parallel but with reverse polarity).
    EDIT: Trying to be even clearer just follow those instructions :
    1 - name the coil's ends :inner end as E (for Entry) and the outer end as O (for Output)
    2- name cell1 2 pins: plus (name it C1+) and minus (name it C1-)
    3- same for cell2 : C2+ C2-
    now interconnect all this as follows :
    C1+ to C2- to E
    C1- to C2+ to O Print the supports ( 2x support1.stl, one support2.stl). The magnets and glass shall slide with force inside the gaps. Glue them in place take care to the magnets orientation on each support. ( see "3D_printed_mendocino_motor-side-north.jpg") Glue the glass and support at the tip of the second carbon rod shaft.
    Insert the shaft inside the both other supports but DO NOT glue them yet. They shall slide with some friction.
    Install the ring magnets on the rotor shaft. use some shrinking tubing or adhesive tape to adapt the shaft diameter to fit in the hole of the magnets. You can glue them on the shaft. To levitate, the extremity magnet shall be placed 2mm in front of the support magnets (in the direction of the glass) while the back magnet shall be nearly aligned with its support (1mm in front of it or so).
    With this, when placing the rotor in levitation, you should feel a small force pushing it towards the glass while in the cross direction you will feel the magnetic field as if the shaft was installed in a V shaped field of forces... And everything shall be stable here !
    If not, it's maybe a matter of distance between the magnets of each support. it's a bit tricky: changing this parameter in support.scad "ec_magnet = 37; // magnets distance" might help as enlarging the distance will increase the lateral stability (The V becomes deeper) but decrease the vertical push... To a certain limit the rotor becomes vertically unstable... But if you use the same magnets as mine it will work without any change !!! Once in levitation, you have to statically balance your rotor. use some sticky mastic (patafix in France) to add mass where needed (stick it first outside the rotor, then when happy with the result, remove the mastic and stick it inside the rotor...) And you're done... it's time to put it in sun light or close to a 60W light bulb, it should turn and accelerate ... I hope plenty babys mendocino will be printed !
    Don't hezitate to contact me in case you need other clarifications. Enjoy ;-) PS : as you may have noticed, there is no other horizontal magnet to produce the Laplace force interacting with the coil current. The magnetic field produced by the support magnets is more than enough. The proper orientation of the magnet (North facing North or South facing South...) is also the reason why it works without another magnet...

comments.text: Could the rotor be kept in position horizontally by using opposing magnets at the ends of the shaft instead of the shaft to glass contact pivot point? If so, that would make it 100% mechanically frictionless.
comments.author: Walt

comments.text:
This could be a clever idea... Theoritically it should work. however, those little rotating machine are very very tricky to balance. The glass + ball pen tip adds a stabitlity in the rotor axis direction (call it X) and the friction of the tip gives also some damping in the Z+Y plane that helps to stabilize the rotor while it is taking speed.
Statically balancing the rotor is quite easy, but dynamic balancing is tricky, On my both motors, there is always some oscillation at the free extremity of the rotor at a given frequency. When I say oscillation it is is the range of +/-5 mm and even more. Then while taking speed this frequency disappears and oscillations too!
comments.author: Walt

comments.text: Ok, I see how the contact helps dampen end movement, and the friction portion is so small that it isn't important. I was just thinking that without any contact, then it could be claimed that the motor is truly mechanically frictionless rather than nearly frictionless (magnetic drag being excluded). You may be able to use a finned paddle wheel added to the shaft to provide some air dampening to keep the speed reasonable and increase stability. The idea of a device that is freely powered and will never wear out, even if it is only for display, has a certain futuristic appeal. Great work!

comments.text: I made one. Its very cool. For those that are having trouble, try the following, first balance the rotor (I used bluetac to start with, then once i had an idea how much to use, I used my hot glue gun to apply a permanent blob of glue under the solar panel. Once balanced, shine filament bulb torch (not LED) at each solar panel. Each will make the motor turn a little. make sure they all turn in the same direction, if not reverse the connections to the odd one. Once that's done, it should work a treat.

description.text:
This adapter is designed to mount an IKEA dioder led lamp into an halogen spot light hole of a IKEA closet.
The adapter fits into a 66 mm hole (odd IKEA spot hole diameter), and has a 80 mm 1,5mm thin bezel.
The design has some slack for the dioder led lamp to allow for 3D print tolerances (hole=52 mm).
I have included the 123d design files so one can modify this design to fit ones needs, and adapt it for larger or smaller holes.
When using natural PLA some light of the LED partly illuminates the bezel.

title: Flashlight grip for sliding bike handlebar mounts

description.text:
This is a parametric mount for attaching a cylindrical flashlight to those sliding
handlebar grips that come with many bike lights (such as this one: http://www.tesco.com/direct/via-velo-white-led-mini-front-light/729-9776.prd?pageLevel=&skuId=729-9776). It's useful if (like me) the slide on your existing bike light has split, and you have a good flashlight/torch which you'd like to use as a bike light. The first print came out slightly small, so I had to file both it and the rail
down, but that may have been a printer miscalibration error. After that it's
worked fine (at least so far), so I'm putting it out to the world in its
current state.

• Measure your slide (here's one if you don't have one already: http://www.amazon.co.uk/Cateye-Flex-Tight-Bracket-22-32/dp/B000P1PZUY/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1363348368&sr=8-7).
  • Customize the SCAD file, either by hand or using the Thingiverse Customizer.
  • Print your mount.
  • If necessary, file it down until it fits.
  • Insert the flashlight, possibly wrapping it in some padding with a bit of give (rubber, duct tape, etc).
  • Insert 1-3 nuts and bolts into the holes in the flanges and tighten until the flashlight doesn't move.
  • Attach the mount to the rail.
  • Attach the rail to the bike.
  • Turn off your computer and printer and go outside for a bike ride.

comments.text: This looks great, but I feel like that tiny sliding thingy is for a much lighter thing than the flashlight I want to mount. I'm looking for a top clamp like yours, that slides down (not back) to clip into another big printed clamp on the handle bars.  Good work though!

title: Floating Filament Guide for Octave Spool

description.text: This is a filament guide that hangs on the same spindle that your spool is mounted to, only it is independent of the spool.  This lets it float up and down, keeping the filament on your spool and not wrapped tightly around your spindle.  It was designed specifically for Octave size spools.  The guide itself clips in/out of the arms that loop around the spindle... this allows for quick change over between spools.  Note, it works extremely well once about 5% of the filament has been used... but a brand new spool should be watched as filament can still slip off.
Simply print 1x the guide, and 2x the arm.  Its pretty self explanatory.

author: thowe

description.text: Just in time for Valentine's Day...hearts for printing on Egg-Bot in various forms (filled/hollow and single/surround). 2011-02-09: I have relabeled this as "In Progress" as I have figured out some improvements. I plan to replace the current files after I test the new versions. The new versions will have less dense hatching for the fill and the outline will start/end in the top crease of the heart instead of on the side so minor registration issues should be hidden.

Load in Inkscape and plot on Egg-Bot. Note: the hatches on the filled heart are pretty dense. For smaller objects you may want to adjust the hatch density before plotting. The hearts were created as follows:
Draw circle
Convert to path (Path -> Object-to-path)
Choose "Edit path by node" tool
Click bottom node
Click "Make selected nodes corner" button
Drag end handles of node to directly above bottom node
Do same with the top node
Adjust shape as desired by shortening/lengthening handles and dragging nodes

comments.text: This looks great! How did you apply the hatching?
comments.author: schmarty

comments.text:
I drew the heart as described above then just used the method described in the egg-bot tutorials (Path -
&
gt; Path Effect Editor -
&
gt; Apply New Effect, Select the "Hatches (rough)" effect and clidk "Add" then use the Egg-Bot extension of preset hatches for fill)
comments.author: schmarty

comments.text: Suddenly the name of that EggBot extension makes sense. I spent a while trying (and failing) to get the "Hatches (rough)" output looking like I wanted thinking that the EggBot extension was some kind of post-processing step to help the EggBot draw the hatches correctly.

title: Prusa i3 RAMPS 1.4 Board & Fan Mount / Holder

description.text: This is a simple RAMPS 1.4 Mount for a Prusa i3 3D Printer which will stand the board off the frame to allow wires to be routed underneath. It has four wire anchor points (2 at bottom and top) which holds the wires in place. The 2 Piece Dual 40mm 12V Fan mount keeps the stepper drivers really cool, and is hinged which makes accessing the RAMPS Board a breeze. Visit our website for our full range of parts at: http://ooznest.co.uk/

Parts needed to complete this mount are: Printed Parts of the attached STL's
RAMPS 1.4 & Arduino Mega2560
2 x 12V DC 40mm Fans
2 x M3 50mm Bolts
8 x M3 20mm Bolts
1 x M3 25mm Bolts
1 x M3 8mm Bolts
12 x M3 Nyloc Nuts
2 x M3 Form A Washers Instructions can be found on Page's 22/37/38 of our Prusa i3 Instruction Manual Here: http://www.ooznest.co.uk/Prusa/Prusa-Instructions-v1.40.pdf Both fans can be attached to the D9 Output of the RAMPS 1.4 & Controlled with G-Code M106 SXXX

title: EQ-2 Camera Quick Shoe Adapter for Slik Pro EZ Quick Plate

description.text:
Just a simple Quick Shoe Adapter for the EQ-2 Telescope Mount.
The Quick Plate which fits this mount is the Slik Quick Release Plate 6183. The EQ-2 Mount has M8 threads, so no nut is necessary.
The Quick Shoe is assembled to the EQ-2 Mount with M3 Screws (no nuts needed)
